questions.question: A 35 year old male presents with perineal pain and swelling after a traumatic injury during a sporting event. On examination, there is significant bruising over the scrotum and penis. Imaging confirms fluid collection in the superficial perineal space. Which of the following structures is most likely affected by the injury?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bulb of the penis Explanation: The bulb of the penis is located in the superficial perineal space, making it vulnerable to injury in this region. The bulb is covered by the bulbospongiosus muscle and contributes to the corpus spongiosum. Pouches in Perineum Superficial Perineal Space Deep Perineal Space Location Below the perineal membrane. Above the perineal membrane. Boundaries Superiorly: Perineal membrane Inferiorly: Colles' fascia (membranous layer of superficial fascia) Laterally: Ischiopubic rami Posteriorly: Fusion of the perineal membrane with Colles' fascia Anteriorly: Continuous with the spaces of the scrotum and penis in males, and the clitoris and anterior abdominal wall in females. Superiorly: Open Inferiorly: Perineal membrane Laterally: Ischiopubic rami Anteriorly: Gap between the perineal membrane and inferior pubic ligament. Contents In males : Root of the penis (corpora cavernosa and corpus spongiosum) Muscles (ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus, superficial transverse perinei) Branches of the perineal nerve and artery Ducts of the bulbourethral glands In females: Body of the clitoris (corpora cavernosa) Bulbs of the vestibule Muscles (ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus, superficial transverse perinei) Branches of the perineal nerve and artery The greater vestibular glands and their ducts In males: Part of the urethra Muscles ( sphincter urethrae in the urethral wall, deep transversus perinei) (Option A) Dorsal nerve of the penis (Option C) Muscular branches from the perineal nerve Artery of the penis Bulbourethral glands In females: Parts of the urethra and vagina Muscles (sphincter urethrae in the urethral wall, deep transversus perinei, compressor urethrae, sphincter urethrovaginalis), Dorsal nerve of the clitoris, Muscular branches from the perineal nerve, Artery of the clitoris, and no glands. Contents of Superficial and Deep Perineal Pouches: Prostate gland (Option D) is located much higher, in the pelvic region, and is not part of the perineal spaces.

questions.question: From the muscles given below, choose the muscles forming the pelvic diaphragm. Levator ani Coccygeus Bulbospongiosus Ischiocavernosus Superficial transverse perineal muscle Deep transverse perineal muscle
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) 1 and 2 Explanation: Levator ani and coccygeus muscles on both sides and their covering fasciae forms the pelvic diaphragm. Pelvic Diaphragm: Definition Muscular partition between the true pelvis and the perineum Components Levator ani and coccygeus muscles on both sides and their covering fasciae Functions Support to the pelvic viscera Sphincteric action on the rectum and vagina Increasing intra-abdominal pressure during defecation, micturition, and parturition Openings 1. Hiatus Urogenitalis: Triangular gap between anterior fibers of the two levator ani muscles. Transmits the urethra in males, and the urethra and vagina in females. 2. Hiatus Rectalis: Round opening between the perineal body and the anococcygeal raphe. Provides passage to the anorectal junction. Reference: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, Volume-2, 2nd Edition, Page 215

questions.question: Choose the wrong pairing of fibers of pubococcygeus with its name.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Posterior fibers-puborectalis Explanation: The middle fibers of pubococcygeus are called puborectalis , not the posterior fibers Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page 494

questions.question: Which of the following lobes of the prostate is responsible for producing uvula vesicae?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Median lobe Explanation: The median lobe of the prostate forms uvula vesicae. Lobe Location Key Features Anterior Lobe In front of the urethra, connecting the two lateral lobes Devoid of glandular tissue Also called isthmus Posterior Lobe Behind the ejaculatory ducts and median lobe Primary site of carcinoma of the prostate Median Lobe Behind the upper part of the urethra and in front of the ejaculatory ducts Wedge-shaped Common site of adenoma Base produces an elevation at the apex of trigonum vesicae called uvula vesicae - A slight elevation in the mucous membrane of urinary bladder immediately above and behind the internal urethral orifice Most commonly enlarged in BPH Lateral Lobes One on each side of the urethra Separated by posterior median sulcus Contains glandular tissue Possible site of adenoma in old age Reference: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, Volume-2, 2nd Edition, Page 242,253

questions.question: A 72-year-old man visits the clinic for evaluation of urinary symptoms, including nocturia, increased urgency, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. During the examination, a digital rectal exam reveals a smooth, enlarged prostate without any palpable nodules. The patient's PSA level is slightly elevated at 5.5 ng/mL. In which zone of the prostate does this condition primarily occur?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Transitional zone Explanation : The above mentioned condition is benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and the transitional zone is primarily responsible for it. Prostate Zones Description Peripheral Zone Extends posterolaterally around the gland from the apex to the base. Represents the most common site in the prostate for developing prostate carcinomas. Transitional Zone Constitutes two small lobules around the prostatic urethra. Represent the region where benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) primarily originates. Carcinomas that originate in the transition zone have been suggested to be of lower malignant potential. Central Zone Surrounds the ejaculatory duct apparatus and makes up the majority of the prostatic base. Less frequently involved in BPH or malignancy. Anterior Fibromuscular Stroma Rarely associated with disease Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK13217/#:~:text=There%20are%20four%20major%20zones,(Fi gure%20111-4).

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent urination, especially at night, and difficulty initiating urination. He reports that he feels an urge to urinate but often has to wait before the stream begins. During the digital rectal exam, the physician notes a smooth, enlarged prostate. Patient has a medical history of diabetes and hyperlipidemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) Explanation: Patient’s symptoms of increased urinary frequency, nocturia, and difficulty initiating urination, along with the finding of an enlarged prostate, are classic signs of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH): Non-malignant enlargement or hyperplasia of the prostate tissue. Common in older men , particularly those over 50 and prevalence increases with age. Hyperplasia results from impaired cell death , resulting in the accumulation of senescent cells in the prostate. Pathophysiology Hormonal changes (increased dihydrotestosterone, DHT) contribute to prostate growth. Proliferation of stromal and epithelial cells, and delayed epithelial cell death in the transitional zone. Risk factors Diabetes mellitus Obesity Metabolic syndrome Heavy caffeine consumption High dose supplemental vitamin-C 1st degree relatives Symptoms Storage Symptoms: Urinary frequency Urgency Nocturia Incontinence (Urgency, stress) Voiding Symptoms: Hesitancy Small stream Intermittency Terminal dribbling Urinary retention Diagnosis Digital rectal exam (DRE) reveals enlarged prostate. Urinalysis to rule out infection. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test to assess for prostate cancer. Urinary flow rate tests can evaluate the severity of obstruction. 24 hour voiding diary Urodynamics Complications Acute urinary retention Urinary tract infections Bladder stones Kidney damage (if untreated) Treatment Alpha-blockers ( tamsulosin ), 5-alpha reductase inhibitors ( finasteride ). Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) Transurethral incision of the prostate Transurethral electrovaporization Holmium and Thulium laser enucleation of the prostate Prostate cancer (Option A) presents similarly but would typically require further evaluation and would more likely present with nodularity or firmness rather than a smooth enlarged prostate. Prostatitis (Option B) causes urinary symptoms but usually associated with pain, fever or dysuria. Urinary tract infection (Option D) causes urinary frequency and urgency but would usually be associated with other symptoms like dysuria or fever.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the prostatic urethra is true?

options.A: It is primarily lined by stratified squamous epithelium.
options.B: It is the shortest segment of the male urethra.
options.C: It connects the bladder to the membranous urethra and receives the ejaculatory ducts.
options.D: It is solely responsible for the passage of urine, with no role in the reproductive system.

questions.explanation: ducts. Correct Answer: C) It connects the bladder to the membranous urethra and receives the ejaculatory ducts. Explanation: Male Urethra is Divided into 4 Parts: Pre-prostatic urethra Prostatic urethra Membranous urethra Spongy urethra Prostatic Urethra: Segment of the male urethra that passes through the prostate gland. Location Widest part of male urethra. (Option B) Contains urethral crest, seminal colliculus, prostatic utricle and orifices of prostatic duct. Extends from the bladder neck to the beginning of the membranous urethra which is approximately 3-4 cm in length . (Option C) Histology Urothelium immediately surrounded by glandular and strong tissue of the periurethral zone of the prostate. (Option A) Functions Conducts urine from the bladder to the external urethral orifice and serves as a passage for semen during ejaculation. (Option D) Associated Structures Receives the ejaculatory ducts , which deliver semen from the seminal vesicles and the vas deferens and contains the prostatic urethral orifices, which allow for the secretion of prostatic fluid. Clinical Significance Can be affected by conditions such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and prostate cancer , leading to urinary obstruction. Digital rectal examination (DRE) can assess the prostate’s condition via the prostatic urethra. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK542238/

questions.question: Which of the following correctly lists the segments of the male urethra in the order they occur from the bladder to the external urethral orifice? → Membranous urethra → Spongy urethra → Membranous urethra → Prostatic urethra → Spongy urethra → Prostatic urethra → Spongy urethra → Membranous urethra
questions.explanation: → Membranous urethra → Spongy urethra Correct Answer: A) Prostatic urethra → Membranous urethra → Spongy urethra Explanation: The correct order of the segments of the male urethra is Prostatic urethra → Membranous urethra → Spongy urethra Male Urethra: Urethra is a dynamic fibromuscular tube which serves as the terminal region of the male urinary and reproductive systems. Average male urethra is 20 cm long and begins within the bladder wall and ends in the distal glans of the penis. Receives blood supply from the inferior vesical artery , bulbourethral artery , and the internal pudendal artery. The sympathetic, parasympathetic and visceral innervation to the male urethra gets delivered through the prostatic plexus. Littre’s glands are small mucous-secreting glands located in the submucosa, along the length of male urethra, primarily in the spongy urethra. Divided into 4 parts: Pre-Prostatic Urethra Location : Extends inferiorly from urinary bladder and ends prior to entering the prostate gland. Gross Features : It is embedded within the walls of the urinary bladder and is typically 0.5 to 1.5 cm in length. Histological Features : Transitional epithelium (urothelium) Prostatic Urethra Location : Completely encompassed within the prostate gland. Gross Features : This is generally the widest part of the male urethra, and contains the urethral crest, seminal colliculus, prostatic utricle, and the orifices of the prostatic ducts - typically 3.0 to 4.0 cm in length. Histological Features : Urothelium immediately surrounded by the glandular and stromal tissue of the periurethral zone of the prostate. Membranous Urethra Location : Begins immediately outside of the prostate and ends just prior to entering the bulb of the penis. Gross Features : Passes through the deep perineal pouch, the external urethral sphincter, and the perineal membrane.Typically 1 to 1.5 cm in length. Histological Features: Pseudostratified columnar epithelium. Spongy Urethra/Penile Urethra Location : Travels the entire length of the penis via the corpus spongiosum. Gross Features: Widens initially as it enters the bulb of the penis and widens again in the glans of the penis, forming the navicular fossa.Typically around 15 cm in length. Histological Features : Pseudostratified columnar epithelium except for the terminal portion which is stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.question: Gynaecologist is planning to do uterine artery ligation. She must be careful while performing it due to the risk of injuring which structure?

options.A: Ureter, as it lies anterior to uterine artery
options.B: Ureter, as it lies posterior to uterine artery
options.C: Bladder, as it lies superior to uterine artery
options.D: Urethra, as it lies inferior to uterine artery

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Ureter, as it lies posterior to uterine artery Explanation: While performing uterine artery ligation, ‘ water under bridge ’ can occur due to injury to Ureter . ‘Water’ refers to urine, due to leak from the ureter and ‘bridge’ is formed by the uterine artery. Ureter lies posteroinferior to the uterine artery. Relations of Arteries with Ureter: Uterine artery is a branch of anterior division of internal iliac artery and ovarian artery is a branch of abdominal aorta , both of which anastomose. Uterine artery is anterosuperior to the ureter by 2.5 cm and then crosses the ureter to ascend along the lateral side of the uterus. Ureter passes forward, just above the lateral fornix of the vagina, and lies about 2 cm to the side of the supravaginal portion of the cervix. It then curves inward toward the urinary bladder, coming into close contact with the vagina. While performing hysterectomy, careful ligation of the uterine artery should be done to prevent this. Presence of peristaltic movements and the pale glistening appearance with firm cord feel on palpation will help in identifying the ureter. Mesenteries Supporting Female Reproductive System: Broad ligament Fold of peritoneum attaching uterus to the lateral pelvic wall Mesovarium Attaches ovary to the posterior layer of broad ligament Mesometrium Part of broad ligament lying between uterine tube and ovarian ligament ( Ovarian ligament: passes from lower pole of ovary to lateral angle of uterus) Suspensory Ligament of the Ovary Part of the broad ligament that stretches from the upper pole of the ovary and the infundibulum of the uterine tube to the lateral pelvic wall Also known as infundibulopelvic ligament

questions.question: Match the branches of uterine arteries with their names based on the image given: 1 a) Basal artery 2 b) Spiral artery 3 c) Arcuate artery 4 d) Radial artery
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b Explanation: Sequence of Uterine Artery: A Arcuate Artery Supplies the myometrium(outer I ) and gives Radial artery The arcuate artery around the cervix is also called the circular artery of the cervix R Radial Artery Supplies the myometrium ( inner I ) Gives Basal artery B Basal Artery Present in the basal endometrium, does not get sloughed off during menstruation Forms vascular layers, known as stratum vasculare S Spiral Artery Present in the innermost layer of endometrium to get sloughed off during menstruation. Spirally arranged to prevent excess bleed during menses

questions.question: A 30 year old female presented with post coital bleeding. Hysterectomy with lymph node dissection was done. Gross specimen of the uterus is shown below. Which of the following nodes group is least likely to be positive for malignancy?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Superficial inguinal Explanation: Clinical scenario and the gross specimen is diagnostic of Carcinoma cervix . Cervix belongs to the lower lymphatics of the uterus that drains into the Internal iliac, obturator & sacral group (never into the inguinal) . Lymphatic Drainage of Uterus: Lymphatics Region Draining Lymph Node Upper Fundus and upper half of uterine body including ovary and fallopian tube Aortic group (Pre- & Lateral aortic) Round ligament and uterine isthmus Superficial inguinal Middle Lower half of uterine body External iliac Lower Cervix Internal iliac, Sacral & Obturator group (never inguinal) Vagina Upper 1/3rd External iliac Middle 1/3rd Internal iliac Lower 1/3rd Superficial inguinal

questions.question: Angle shown in the image below in a non-gravid uterus is maintained by?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Both (A) and (B) Explanation: Angle shown in the image between the cervix and vagina is known as the Angle of Anteversion. Angle between the uterus and cervix is known as the Angle of Anteflexion . Uterus is maintained in an anteverted state mainly by Round ligament with minor contribution from uterosacral ligament in non-pregnant female. (Hence, Option C would be most appropriate) Angle of Anteversion & Anteflexion: Angle of Anteversion Description Angle between long axis of cervix and long axis of vagina Angle Normal: 90° Maintained by Non-pregnant female: Round ligament (main) + uterosacral ligament (Option C) Pregnant female: Round ligament only Angle of Anteflexion Description Angle between long axis of uterus and long axis of cervix Angle Normal: 120°-170° Maintained by Uterosacral ligament Pelvic Fascia: The pelvic fascia is categorized into sections covering the pelvic wall, floor, and viscera. Fascia of the Pelvic Wall: Tough and membranous, covering the obturator internus and piriformis muscles and attaching to the bone margins. Fascia of the Pelvic Floor: Looser and less dense, covered by the parietal layer of pelvic fascia. Fascia Surrounding the Pelvic Viscera: Loosely structured, often containing areolar tissue, allowing for the distension of pelvic organs. Deep Endopelvic Connective Tissue Condenses to Form the Following Ligaments: Mackenrodt’s Ligaments Formed by condensation of parietal fascia covering the obturator internus. Distal part of the ureter passes under the uterine artery within the upper part of the cardinal ligament. Function: Lateral stabilization to the cervix at the
